title: Quarto for Report Makers
text:
About this
This is a book using Quarto for generating reports. These can range from parameterised and automatic reports, to draft reports halfway on the way to publication.
This books content was initially drafted during the 2025 OceaniaR Hackathon in Canberra. It spawned from shared experiences of users generating primarily internal reports, working through hurdles and tricks on working with dynamic text, parameterisation, and multi-output formats.


Why does it exist?
This book looks to distil principles for best practice and hot tips for dynamic/reproducible quarto coding. Some amazing Quarto resources are out there already, likeÂ Quarto for ScientistsÂ by Nicholas Tierney. This book will contribute to this pool of knowledge, providing some best practice principles for using Quarto in a functional and dynamic way.

2.1 Templated reporting
There are a number of benefits to investing in templated or parameterised reporting:
That said it does not come without its costs. Transforming ad-hoc processes to more structured end to end reports can be quite an investment, particularly if users arenâ€™t already using the processes. It is advisableot consider building a Quarto template of a report to be a capital investment. You spend the additional effort to build up the capability to develop reports quicker, more consistently and even automatically.
Additionally, there may be small hurdles in the processes that. Things like specific formatting, unique organisation requirements on things like table of chart formats. From a cost benefit perspective, adopting these benefits may often mean sacrificing things like specific unique formatting requirements.
Templated reporting is not without all faults.
